core_claim: Post-it Notes were invented accidentally when a scientist at 3M was trying to develop a super-strong adhesive but instead created an unusually weak one that could be peeled off surfaces without leaving residue.
source_citation: 3M Company Archives; Spencer Silver's patents (US Patent 3,691,140); The Great Idea Finder historical records
why_strange: A complete failure at its intended purpose became one of the most successful office products in history.

core_claim: Viagra (sildenafil) was originally developed as a medication for angina and hypertension, but during clinical trials, researchers discovered its unexpected side effect of treating erectile dysfunction.

supporting_details.original_purpose: Treatment for angina pectoris and hypertension
supporting_details.unexpected_observation: Male test subjects reported frequent erections during clinical trials

source_citation: British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 1996; FDA approval documents; Pfizer company history
why_strange: A cardiovascular drug's 'side effect' became its primary purpose, creating a multi-billion dollar market that hadn't previously existed.

core_claim: Bubble Wrap was originally invented in 1957 as a textured wallpaper, then marketed as greenhouse insulation before finally finding success as a packaging material.
source_citation: Sealed Air Corporation archives; Patents US2917217 and US3033702; Smithsonian Institution records
why_strange: A failed decorative wall covering became one of the most ubiquitous packaging materials in the world.

core_claim: The microwave oven was invented after engineer Percy Spencer noticed a chocolate bar melting in his pocket while working near an active radar set at Raytheon Corporation in 1945.
source_citation: Raytheon Company archives; IEEE History Center; US Patent 2,495,429 (filed October 8, 1945)
why_strange: A wartime radar engineer's melting candy bar led to a kitchen appliance that revolutionized how people prepare food worldwide.

core_claim: The microwave oven was invented accidentally when engineer Percy Spencer noticed a chocolate bar melted in his pocket while working on a radar system.
source_citation: National Museum of American History, Smithsonian Institution; Raytheon Company archives
why_strange: A common kitchen appliance was born from a radar-related mishap

core_claim: Play-Doh was originally created in the 1930s as a wallpaper cleaner before being repurposed as a children's toy in the 1950s.

supporting_details.participants: Kutol Products Company; Joseph and Noah McVicker
supporting_details.original_use: Non-toxic compound to clean coal soot from wallpaper
supporting_details.rebranding: Renamed Play-Doh and marketed by Rainbow Crafts

source_citation: Cincinnati Enquirer archives; Smithsonian Magazine, 'The Accidental History of Play-Doh', 2016
why_strange: A popular children's toy started as a household cleaning product

core_claim: Coca-Cola was invented as a medicinal tonic containing cocaine and alcohol, initially marketed as a cure for morphine addiction and nervous disorders.

supporting_details.participants: Dr. John Stith Pemberton, pharmacist and Civil War veteran
supporting_details.original ingredients: Coca leaf extract (cocaine), kola nut extract (caffeine), wine

source_citation: Coca-Cola Company archives; Mark Pendergrast, 'For God, Country, and Coca-Cola', 2000
why_strange: One of the world's most famous soft drinks began as a cocaine-laced medicine

core_claim: Play-Doh, the popular modeling compound for children, was originally marketed and sold as a wallpaper cleaner in the 1930s.

supporting_details.participants: Kutol Products, Noah McVicker (inventor), Joseph McVicker (marketing), Kay Zufall (teacher who suggested toy use)
supporting_details.transition: A nursery school teacher, Kay Zufall, heard about the product and suggested its use as a modeling material for children, leading to its rebranding in 1956.

source_citation: Smithsonian Magazine, 'The Accidental Invention of Play-Doh'; Cincinnati Magazine, 'The Amazing History of Play-Doh'
why_strange: A common household cleaning product was repurposed to become one of the most iconic children's toys.

core_claim: The microwave oven was invented after a Raytheon engineer, Percy Spencer, noticed a radar magnetron melted a chocolate bar in his pocket during an experiment.

supporting_details.discovery_event: While working on an active radar set, Spencer felt a strange sensation and discovered the chocolate bar in his pocket had melted. He then intentionally experimented with popcorn kernels and an egg.
supporting_details.first_commercial_product: The 'Radarange' in 1947, which was over 6 feet tall, weighed more than 750 pounds, and cost approximately $5,000.

source_citation: Smithsonian National Museum of American History, 'Food History: The Microwave Oven'; Raytheon Company, 'The Invention of the Microwave Oven'
why_strange: A fundamental kitchen appliance was discovered by accident due to a melting candy bar.

core_claim: The Slinky, a classic toy, was accidentally invented by a naval mechanical engineer who was trying to develop springs to stabilize sensitive instruments on ships.

supporting_details.discovery_event: James was working with tension springs and accidentally knocked one off a shelf, observing how it 'walked' down a stack of books and onto the floor.
supporting_details.first_sale: Gimbels department store, Philadelphia, where 400 Slinkys sold out in 90 minutes during the 1945 Christmas season, priced at $1 each.

source_citation: Smithsonian National Museum of American History, 'Slinky'; The Strong National Museum of Play, 'Slinky'
why_strange: A serious military engineering project unexpectedly led to the creation of one of the world's most enduring and simple toys.
